I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Republic of Indonesia for the Higher Education for Technology and Innovation Project. 
 
2.  The proposed project will support the government’s human capital development agenda 
by strengthening the capacity of two public universities—the Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember 
(ITS) in East Java Province and Universitas Lampung (UNILA) in Lampung Province—to provide 
cutting  edge  higher  education  and  high-quality  research—two  key  drivers  of  technology 
development and innovation. It will provide world-class academic facilities and innovation centers, 
and will strengthen faculty, staff, and student capacity to teach, research, and innovate. It will 
support the construction of a teaching hospital to boost capacity to develop high-quality health 
personnel and provide quality medical services to respond to increased demand for health 
services, including those triggered by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic. The project 
will provide new research facilities and grants to stimulate commercialization of new products and 
foster collaboration between universities and industry. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  Macroeconomic context. Indonesia sustained average annual economic growth of 5.0% 
from 2015 to 2019, accompanied by low inflation, a credible fiscal framework, a moderate current 
account deficit, and structural reforms to improve the business climate. Private consumption 
remained a lead contributor to GDP, followed by investment. However, Indonesia's economy 
contracted by 2.1% in 2020 because of the significant economic disruption caused by COVID-19. 
Consumption  in  Indonesia  contracted  by  2.7%  in  2020  as  households  cut  spending  and 
businesses postponed investment.1 Over the medium-term, the challenge will be returning the 
economy  to  its  pre-pandemic  growth trajectory,  while  also diversifying growth sources  and 
improving productivity to ensure that growth is inclusive and resilient. 
 
4.  COVID-19 impact on higher education. In addition to its devastating impact on health 
and economy, COVID-19 has also disrupted education including higher education, with school 
closures necessitating an abrupt shift to distance and online learning. Some universities with 
limited capacity in terms of technology and tools faced problems delivering online classes.  
Students’ and faculties’ access to learning and research was also constrained by the lack of their 
access to internet and effective online teaching materials.  
 
5.  Persistent challenges in higher education. The higher education subsector continues 
to be affected by underfunding, which has resulted in low levels of quality, relevance, access, and 
equity. The shortage of skilled professionals in high-growth sectors and higher-than-average 
unemployment of higher education graduates in associated fields are evident. This reflects the 
disconnect between higher education institutions (HEIs) and the economic drivers which require 
technological skills and relevant research outcomes. In February 2021, the Indonesian Central 
Bureau of Statistics reported 6.18 million unemployed.  While the average unemployment rate for 
all levels of educational attainment was 6.26%, unemployment rate for post-secondary diploma 
holders and bachelor’s degree holders were 6.61% and 6.97%, respectively.2 The labor force 
 
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2021. Asian Development Outlook 2021: Financing a Green and Inclusive 
Recovery.  Manila. 
2  Government of Indonesia, Statistics Indonesia. 2021. National Labor Force Survey. Jakarta.

2 
participation rate for women in 2020 remained much lower (51.89%) than for men (83.13%). 
Despite an increase in their education levels, 63.35% of female employment continue to be 
concentrated in the informal sector, compared with 57.29% of men.3 
 
6.  Quality issues. Access to higher education has improved, with the gross enrollment rate 
rising from 14.8% in 1999 to 31% in 2019. As of 2019, there were about 8.5 million students 
enrolled in more than 4,600 HEIs, including 122 public universities under the Directorate General 
of Higher Education of the Ministry of Education, Culture, Research and Technology (MOECRT). 
However, quality remains a concern. In 2018, about 38% of HEIs were accredited, of which about 
4% had obtained level A, the highest level of accreditation, while 36% had attained level B and 
60%, level C.4 No Indonesian HEI was in the top 500 of the Times Higher Education world 
university rankings in 2020, while only three were in the top 500 of the QS World University 
Rankings.5 Quality deficits largely account for the mismatch between educational attainment and 
employment outcomes. Lack of access to quality higher education disproportionately affects poor 
students. Producing better-educated health care professionals is another important prerequisite 
to  developing  a  healthy  and  productive  workforce.  This  requires  investment  and  policy 
interventions  to  modernize  higher  education  delivery  through  revised  pedagogy,  improved 
facilities, and enhanced human resources. 
 
7.  Need to strengthen human capital in the health sector. To improve human capital for 
economic growth, the government has set a target of universal health coverage. The health care 
system requires better-trained health professionals; more hospitals, including teaching hospitals; 
more medical schools;  and medical  research centers.6 There  are  only 21  doctors  (general 
practitioners), five dentists, 138 nurses, and 84 midwives per 100,000 people in the country, and 
just 16 general practitioners per 100,000 people in Lampung Province.7 Before the COVID-19 
pandemic, Indonesia had only 118 hospital beds per 100,000 people and 2.7 critical care beds 
per 100,000 people, which was among the lowest in 23 Asian countries.8 The rapid spread of 
COVID-19 in Indonesia has further strained its already overburdened health system, causing the 
country to fall further behind its regional peers in key health indicators. 
 
8.  Capacity constraints on research and innovation. Teaching and learning approaches 
have failed to keep pace with global trends involving active learning in which students are not 
simply passive recipients of teaching practices. The soft skills required in the 4IR labor market 
are not well-developed in most HEI graduates in Indonesia. Physical facilities for teaching, 
learning, and research are limited and there is a shortage of skilled and knowledgeable faculty 
and lecturers to teach specialized subjects and carry out basic, applied, and industry-responsive 
research. 
 
9.  Importance of technological transformation. The Government of Indonesia recognizes 
the role of technological transformation in promoting innovation, increasing labor productivity, and

new product development, and ease entry into new markets, allowing industries to become more 
productive.  Technological  transformation  will  play  a  critical  role  in  enhancing  Indonesia’s 
innovation capacity  and  global  competitiveness  in  the  era  of  Industry 4.0  (fourth  industrial 
revolution  [4IR]).10  Technological transformation,  disruption,  and  innovation  are  progressing 
quickly and impacting all sectors of the Indonesian economy. At the same time, they are creating 
opportunities for higher economic growth and employment, with new and emerging types of work 
that require better education and training.11 Most new work in high-value, technology-driven 
sectors requires high-level skills, including soft skills.12 To benefit from technology’s productivity 
boost, Indonesia needs to accelerate efforts to provide the high-level skills demanded by the labor 
market, expand robust research to support innovation, and maintain a healthy workforce. 
 
10.  Lack of global competitiveness and innovation capacity. Indonesia is relatively weak 
in innovation. In 2019, Indonesia ranked 50th out of 141 economies in the World Economic 
Forum’s Global Competitiveness Index.13 Indonesia ranked 85th out of 129 economies in the 2020 
Global Innovation Index that references 80 indicators for innovation, including education and 
infrastructure.14 One of the reasons for the lack of competitiveness and low innovation score may 
be the short supply of researchers. A 2018 comparison with Southeast Asian counterparts shows 
that Indonesia had 216 researchers per million people, compared with 1,350 in Thailand and 708 
in Viet Nam.15 A strengthened higher education system will increase the number of researchers 
and highly skilled workers for 4IR.  
 
11.  Need to promote innovation in addressing vulnerability to climate change. Indonesia 
is  extremely  vulnerable  to  climate  change.16  Without  well-planned  climate  adaptation  and 
disaster-risk-reduction  efforts,  poor  and  marginalized  communities  are  likely  to  experience 
significant loss and damage because of climate change. In its Nationally Determined Contribution 
under the Paris Agreement, the government has set ambitious climate mitigation and adaptation 
goals.17 Promoting resource-efficient development based on technological innovation is critical in 
achieving these goals. 
 
12.  Strategic alignment. Indonesia’s National Medium-Term Development Plan (RPJMN), 
2020–2024  emphasizes  strengthening  higher  education  to  support  technological  change, 
innovation, and entrepreneurship for human capital development (footnote 9). The project is 
strategically aligned with the government priorities of improving access to quality higher education 
in science, engineering, and health; establishing stronger collaborations with industry to increase 
the relevance of education and research; increasing the commercialization of research; and 
strengthening teacher quality. The project will contribute to the government’s aim of expanding 
science techno parks for teaching and research, strengthening and creating new centers of 
excellence  (COEs),  and  creating  additional  student  spaces  through  new  and  expanded

professionals. In addition to strengthening medical graduate quality, the project will provide a 100-

The  project  modality  supports  the  government’s  medium-term  higher  education  investment 
priorities, including concrete interventions to implement policy reforms that will require substantial 
financing. These include investments in facilities construction, equipment upgrading, and capacity 
development. 
 
13.  ITS and UNILA. Several development partners are delivering or planning higher education 
projects in the next five years.21 To complement this support and accelerate moving more HEIs 
toward world class university status, the government has requested support from ADB to invest 
in two public universities: ITS and UNILA. ITS is a leading public HEI specializing in science, 
technology, engineering, and arts. It is ranked in the top 800 of the QS World University Rankings 
and is considered a top 10 Indonesian university. The project will build on ITS’ strengths in key 
technology areas that serve national and multinational industrial partners through highly qualified 
graduates, research and innovation products, and industrial collaborations, leading to value-
added manufacturing. Its location in East Java facilitates access for students and industry in less-
developed eastern Indonesia to high-quality education and research, thus contributing to the 
government’s  objective  of  achieving  regional  equity.  UNILA,  centrally  located  in  Lampung 
Province, has a functioning medical school and a strong potential to provide quality medical 
education and research. The project support for UNILA will contribute to improved health care in 
an off-Java location and more equitable access to high-quality medical education, services, and 
research that will help to address regional health problems. 
 
14.  Lessons learned. Lessons from past ADB-supported projects and technical assistance, 
including in Indonesia, are incorporated into the project design.22 These include (i) university–
industry links lead to market-relevant education programs and increase innovation potential; (ii) 
focusing support on fewer institutions with cost-effective investments is likely to have greater 
development impact; and (iii) developing knowledge and research partnerships in cutting edge 
areas enhances innovation and productivity.

B.  Project Description 
 
15.  The project is aligned with the following impact: human capital enhanced to improve 
competitiveness and productivity (footnote 9). The project will have the following outcome: quality 
and relevance of targeted HEIs improved.23 
 
16.  Output 1: Cutting edge education and research in priority sectors delivered by 
Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember. This output aims to improve the teaching and learning 
quality and research capacity of ITS in the following four specialized areas: (i) creative industry 
(including  product,  graphic,  digital,  and  interior  design;  fashion  crafts;  packaging;  and 
architecture);  (ii)  maritime  technology  (designing  ships/vessels);  (iii)  automotive  (electric 
vehicles); and (iv) advanced information and communication technology and robotics.24 The 
project will construct innovation centers for each of these four specialized areas, with state-of-
the-art  equipment  to  support  effective  teaching  and  learning  and  advanced  research  and 
innovation. These innovation centers will be located within the existing ITS Science Techno Park 
and will contribute to, and complement, ITS’s ongoing COE initiatives. The project will also 
construct an academic building fully equipped with classrooms and laboratories and a cultural 
and language center which will enhance ITS’s international recognition.25  
 
17.  Output 1 will boost key disciplines and thematic knowledge and pedagogical skills, including 
new teaching and learning strategies, and improve research and innovation skills of ITS academic 
and technical staff, through (i) technical and management training programs, both national and 
international; and (ii) engaging ITS staff and students in one or more new programs on applied 
research and entrepreneurship, start-up innovation, training, and certification in the four specialized 
areas. The output will also (i) provide research and entrepreneurship grants to ITS academic staff, 
students, and industrial partners in key specializations to generate knowledge and innovations; (ii) 
expand knowledge partnerships to promote applied research, entrepreneurship development, and 
start-ups; and (iii) increase industry partnerships in skills development, research, and innovation. 
The  project  will  promote  and closely monitor  women’s  participation  in  capacity-strengthening 
programs  and  research  opportunities  to  ensure  gender  equity.  It  will  also  address  climate 
vulnerability through climate-smart and disaster-resilient design of facilities and provide training on 
climate-resilient and resource-efficient campus design and waste and wastewater treatment.  With 
the project support, ITS enrollment is expected to increase by 3,621 undergraduates, 750 master’s 
students, and 250 doctor of philosophy students during project implementation.  
 
18.  Output  2:  Medical  education  and  research  capacity  of  Universitas  Lampung 
strengthened. This output will support improving the quality of medical education at UNILA and 
contribute to developing qualified health professionals in Lampung Province and its vicinity. It will 
also support construction of a pandemic-ready teaching hospital, which will be gender-responsive, 
accessible, energy-efficient, climate- and disaster-resilient, and supplied with essential medical 
and laboratory equipment.26 It will be a type C teaching hospital, which will accommodate a broad 
array of patients, provide diverse case-types, and expand hands-on learning opportunities for

UNILA’s medical students.27 The hospital will include facilities that support health care in several 
specialized fields, including tropical infectious diseases, endocrine and other metabolic disorders, 
geriatrics, and rehabilitative medicine. The project will also construct a new integrated research 
center, physically and operationally connected to the new teaching hospital and the Faculty of 
Medicine, which will specialize in life sciences research and house multidisciplinary research 
programs on health and life sciences.28 The research center will have five laboratories to pursue 
research in tropical medicine; biomolecular, genetic, and degenerative diseases; pathology and 
toxicology; nutrition; and clinical and diagnostic trials. The laboratories will enhance the research 
capacity of UNILA’s faculty, staff, and students, and will underpin UNILA plans to develop COEs 
in one or more of the research foci. 
 
19.  Output 2 will also support capacity development of academic and professional staff from 
the UNILA Faculty of Medicine and other faculties through longer-term internships and exchanges 
at leading domestic and international institutions, which will strengthen their knowledge and skills 
in (i) teaching and research in medicine, health, and life sciences; and (ii) managing, operating, 
and maintaining a teaching hospital and integrated research center. The training programs will 
ensure  equitable  participation  of  female  staff.29  The  project  will  expand  partnerships  with 
industries  in  skills  development,  research,  and  innovation  in  disciplines  supported  by  the 
integrated research center. The Faculty of Medicine will partner with neighboring hospitals and 
the local government in delivering training and contract research, and conducting clinical trials for 
local industry and government. With the project support, enrollment at the UNILA Faculty of 
Medicine is expected to increase by 200 from 2023 to 2026. 
 
C.  Value Added by ADB 
 
20.  ADB’s support builds on its long-standing and unique partnership with Indonesia in higher 
and vocational education and skills development. ADB has partnered with the government in 
support of policy, institutional, and systemic reforms in education involving human resource 
development, strengthening of teaching and learning, and knowledge creation (footnote 22). The 
ongoing Advanced Knowledge and Skills for Sustainable Growth Project illustrates the shared 
intentions and strong collaboration between the government and ADB to support innovation and 
advance higher education reforms.30 The project will complement ongoing and planned ADB 
technical assistance to support the MOECRT’s digital initiatives to improve learning outcomes 
and accelerate online education in Indonesia.31 Lessons from previous projects will add value in 
terms of fostering knowledge partnerships between national and international universities and 
industries to catalyze innovation and deliver cutting edge technology in teaching, learning, and 
research. ADB’s extensive engagement in education, skills development, and health in Indonesia 
will help the government achieve its human development priorities. ADB’s COVID-19 Active

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
27.  The two universities have committed to develop environmentally sustainable and socially 
inclusive campuses. The design of project facilities will adhere to safe, low-carbon, green, climate- 
and disaster-resilient, and inclusive facility design principles.35 The project will promote the 
application  of  rooftop solar  photovoltaics  and  water  conservation,36  rooftop  greening, smart

14/PRT/M/2017 on Ease-of-Access Requirements to Buildings and No. 02/PRT/M/2015 on Green Buildings.

9 
facade shading, and natural ventilation. The MOECRT, ITS, and UNILA have committed to 
allocate  sufficient  budget  and  mobilize qualified  faculty  and staff  to manage  operation  and 
maintenance of facilities and equipment. The capacity development plan includes additional 
training for ITS and UNILA faculty and staff in new technology related to the project, including 
training in operation and maintenance of new equipment. 
 
28.  As the impact of COVID-19 is evolving, the project will be responsive and flexible in 
meeting emerging needs and new guidelines. The project will strictly follow government guidelines 
on safe working in COVID-19 conditions, adhering to the most robust medical and scientific 
advice. Project parties will be required to incorporate emerging international best practices in 
construction.  These  will  include  using  forced  air  ventilation  system;  personal  protective 
equipment; and appropriate implementation methodologies, especially for work in deep trenches 
and other confined spaces where the risk of transmission is high. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial Viability 
 
29.  The economic analysis focused on the direct benefits accruing from an increase in 
enrolled, educated, and subsequently employed graduates, in particular the higher proportion of 
higher degree graduates and medical doctors.37 An additional 4,821 students are expected to 
enroll at ITS and UNILA, given the project interventions. The project’s estimated net present value 
(using a 6% discount rate) is $172.7 million, and the estimated economic internal rate of return is 
11.1%, which is above the economic opportunity cost of investment of 6%. The financial internal 
rate of return, computed on an after-tax basis, is 16.1% against the weighted average cost of 
capital  of  1.9%.  The  project  is  considered  both  economically  and  financially  viable  and 
sustainable. Sensitivity analysis indicates that both the economic and financial internal rates of 
return are robust under adverse conditions.38 Fiscal impact analysis confirms that the government 
has adequate financial resources and will be able to fulfill its financial obligations under the project. 
 
C.  Sustainability 
 
30.  The central government, through the MOECRT, and ITS and UNILA have committed 
adequate counterpart financing to the project. Sources of counterpart funding for both universities 
include tax-free revenue from tuition and central government allocations to each institution’s 
annual operating budget. Project interventions will increase the universities’ nontax revenues 
because  of  growth  in  student  enrollment  and  income  from  expanded  research  and 
entrepreneurship activities. The teaching hospital and integrated research center at UNILA will 
generate new revenue streams from health services such as inpatient and outpatient treatment. 
Post-construction operational costs for the teaching hospital and integrated research center at 
UNILA will be funded by the MOECRT, UNILA, the Ministry of Health, and Indonesia’s Social 
Insurance Administration Organization which administers the national health insurance. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
31.  The public financial management system in Indonesia has several important strengths 
that will help ensure sound financial reporting and oversight. This includes an automated financial 
management information system with a defined central treasury management system, consistent 
accounting and budgetary classifications, and convergence of national accounting and auditing

38  Economic and Financial Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
standards  with  international  standards.39  The  automated  financial  management  information 
system enhances the transparency, credibility, and accuracy of financial information pertaining to 
public funds. At the project level, the MOECRT, UNILA, and ITS have fully automated financial 
management  systems  with  adequate  financial  reporting  and  oversight.  These  financial 
management systems feature a well-developed accounting system and robust links between 
planning,  budgeting,  and  accounting.  The  internal  audit  functions  in  the  executing  and 
implementing  agencies  provide  independent  oversight.  The  executing  and  implementing 
agencies  are  also  regularly  audited  by  independent  external  auditors.  The  assessed  pre-
mitigation financial management risk is moderate mainly because staff of the executing and 
implementing  agencies  lack familiarity  with  ADB’s financial  management  and  disbursement 
requirements.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  the  project  will  (i)  engage  procurement  and  financial 
management staff for the project management unit (PMU) in the MOECRT and the project 
implementation units (PIUs) in UNILA and ITS, and (ii) conduct trainings and briefings for relevant 
PMU and PIU staff on ADB financial management and disbursement requirements. 
 
32.  Procurement of goods, works, and consulting services will be undertaken in compliance 
with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement 
Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as amended from time to time). A procurement capacity 
assessment concluded that ITS and UNILA have limited capacity to implement ADB procurement 
procedures and administer construction contracts. Project management consultants will provide 
technical support. The project will achieve value for money by (i) using e-procurement to lower 
transaction costs and enhance transparency; (ii) consolidating civil works into larger packages to 
attract  large,  technically  strong  contractors  to  bid  for  construction;  and  (iii)  applying  open 
competitive  bidding  with  international  advertisement  for  medical  and  production  equipment, 
software,  and  machinery  to  attract  not  only  national  distributors  but  also  international 
manufacturers and distributors, thereby increasing competition. 
 
33.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government, ITS, and UNILA. The specific policy requirements and supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 34). 
 
E.  Poverty, Social, and Gender 
 
34.  The government, ITS, and UNILA have taken steps to improve equity of access to higher 
education by mobilizing their own resources and other development partners’ support to expand 
scholarship programs for financially disadvantaged students. The project will equip students of 
the two targeted public universities, including poor and disadvantaged students, with the skills to 
secure high-quality, higher-paying jobs and income-earning opportunities. Female participation in 
higher education and the labor market is improving, but women continue to face barriers in 
accessing  capacity-building  programs  and  research  and  entrepreneurship  opportunities  to 
improve their knowledge and skills. This affects the share of women in the labor force and 
women’s access to well-paid employment and job security. Prevailing gender norms and systemic 
gender barriers prevent women from achieving their full potential; affirmative action will be 
required to ensure equality in the job market. Only 31% of ITS academic staff are women, with a 
smaller proportion in disciplines such as maritime and automotive technology (20%). Female 
academic staff are also underrepresented at UNILA, accounting for less than 40% of faculty (the 
Faculty of Medicine is an exception, with 60% women). The project is categorized effective gender 
mainstreaming at entry, and a gender action plan has been prepared. Gender actions include (i) 
maintaining the consistently high proportion of female students in the UNILA Faculty of Medicine

F.  Safeguards 
 
35.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows. 
 
36.  Environment (category B). Initial environmental examinations for the proposed facilities 
at ITS and UNILA have been conducted and the findings have been disclosed in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009).41 ITS and UNILA carried out meaningful consultations 
with key stakeholders, including university staff and nearby communities. Further consultations 
will be carried out before and during construction. Environmental management plans for the 
facility construction have been prepared to mitigate the environmental impacts identified in the 
initial environmental examinations, including on spoil and construction waste management, air 
quality and noise, temporary traffic management, and occupational and community health and 
safety. It is anticipated that adverse impacts will be limited to the construction period. They will be 
temporary and site-specific and can be readily mitigated through sound construction practices. All 
facilities will be constructed within the existing campuses of ITS and UNILA. No significant 
adverse  impacts  on,  or  disruptions  of,  university  activities  are  anticipated  during  facility 
construction. The PMU and PIUs will assign qualified staff to coordinate implementation of the 
environmental management plans. They will be supported by environment and construction safety 
specialists to be recruited under the project. Grievance redress committees, chaired by the PIU 
directors, will be established at both campuses to address project-related complaints. 
 
37.  Involuntary  resettlement  (category  C).  The  project  is  classified  category  C  for 
involuntary resettlement, as per ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The research centers, 
academic building, cultural and language center at ITS, and the teaching hospital and integrated 
research center at UNILA will be constructed on existing land located within the boundaries of 
these two universities. There are no people using or occupying the land, and therefore, involuntary 
resettlement is not expected. Thus, preparation of a resettlement plan and social safeguard 
monitoring report is not needed. 
 
38.  Indigenous peoples (category C). The project is not expected to affect indigenous 
peoples as there are no indigenous peoples living in the project areas. The indigenous peoples 
safeguards requirements will not be triggered by the research and partnership activities.42

i     Available female students and staff refer to those in the specialized priority areas.

16  Appendix 1 
j   Creative industry include product, graphic, digital, and interior design; fashion crafts; packaging; and architecture. 
k  Details on the training plan and other capacity development activities are in Appendix 1 of the project administration 
manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
l  Details on female staff participation in training in specialized areas are in Appendix 1 of the project administration 
manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). The target female staff participation percentage 
reflects existing proportions of female teaching and support staff in each of the target specialized areas. 
m  “Pandemic-ready” means having isolation wards; wards capable of quick conversion to expanded intensive care 
units; isolation capacity to protect non-pandemic patients and provide for their care; ventilation equipment; personal 
protective equipment and management; and World Health Organization-recommended pandemic preparedness 
management practices, including regional coordination with other health service providers and regulators. 
n  As part of the applied research programs, at least one climate adaptation initiative will be designed to increase the 
resilience of Lampung Province’s public health sector to climate change and variability. Health-related risks covered 
by this initiative may include heat stroke and chronic kidney disease resulting from prolonged exposure to high 
temperatures and heatwaves; dengue and malaria; typhoid fever, cholera, leptospirosis, and hepatitis A resulting 
from floods and inundation; smoke inhalation from forest fires/wildfires; and trauma injuries resulting from extreme 
events such as precipitation-induced landslides. The climate adaptation initiative will feed into initiatives of the United 
Nations Development Programme Sustainable Development Goals Centers of Excellence in Indonesia. These 
centers of excellence, composed of 50 leading Indonesian universities, integrate Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs) into the curriculum, conduct academic research to foster innovation to achieve the SDGs, and prepare public 
policy papers to stimulate public discussion in seeking SDG solutions. 
o  Staff from the Faculty of Science (40% female), Faculty of Engineering (26% female), and Faculty of Agriculture 
(36% female) will also be trained.

The proposed project will support the government’s human capital development agenda by strengthening the capacity of two public universities—the Institut Teknologi Sepuluh Nopember (ITS) in East Java Province and Universitas Lampung (UNILA) in Lampung Province—to provide cutting edge higher education and high-quality research—two key drivers of technology development and innovation.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated August 2021 is provided for the ADB project 52332-001 in Indonesia.
